{{infobox book | name = The Beginnings of Western Science<ref name="press.uchicago.edu">[http://press.uchicago.edu/ucp/books/book/chicago/B/bo5550077.html "''The Beginnings of Western Science'' by David C. Lindberg"], ''University of Chicago Press'' (Publisher's page). Retrieved 4 October 2015.</ref> | image = The Beginnings of Western Science.jpg| image_size = | caption = | alt = | author = [[David C. Lindberg]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | subject = [[History of science]] | published = 1992 ([[University of Chicago Press]]) | media_type = | pages = 480 | isbn = 9780226482057 | oclc = | dewey = | congress = Q124.95 .L55 2007 | preceded_by = | followed_by = | wikisource = }}
'''''The Beginnings of Western Science''''', subtitled ''The European Scientific Tradition in Philosophical, Religious, and Institutional Context, 600 B.C. to A.D. 1450'' (1992 edition)<ref>[https://books.google.nl/books/about/The_Beginnings_of_Western_Science.html ''The Beginnings of Western Science: The European Scientific Tradition in Philosophical, Religious, and Institutional Context, 600 B.C. to A.D. 1450'' by David C. Lindberg,] ''Google Books''. Retrieved 4 October 2015.</ref> or ''The European Scientific Tradition in Philosophical, Religious, and Institutional Context, Prehistory to A.D. 1450'' (2007 edition),<ref>[https://books.google.nl/books?id=KhYdmAEACAAJ ''The Beginnings of Western Science: The European Scientific Tradition in Philosophical, Religious, and Institutional Context, Prehistory to A.D. 1450'' by David C. Lindberg,] ''Google Books''. Retrieved 4 October 2015.</ref> is an introductory<ref>A. Bowdoin Van Riper, [http://depts.washington.edu/hssexec/library_list.html#class "READING THE HISTORY OF WESTERN SCIENCE" under "Classical science (to 1500 AD)"], ''History of Science Society''. Retrieved 4 October 2015.</ref> book on the [[history of science]] by [[David C. Lindberg]]. The book focuses on what is called Western science, prominently covering [[History of science in classical antiquity|Greek, Roman]], [[Science in the medieval Islamic world|Islamic]] and [[European science in the Middle Ages|Mediaeval European science]], while the 2007 second edition expands on precursors to Greek science, such as Mesopotamian and Egyptian science, and on Islamic science.<ref name="press.uchicago.edu">[http://press.uchicago.edu/ucp/books/book/chicago/B/bo5550077.html "''The Beginnings of Western Science'' by David C. Lindberg"], ''University of Chicago Press'' (Publisher's page). Retrieved 4 October 2015.</ref> "Western science" is defined as scientific enquiry done in [[Ancient Greek language|Greek]], [[Latin language|Latin]] or [[Arabic language|Arabic]] according to reviewer William A. Wallace.<ref>William A. Wallace, "David C. Lindberg, The Beginnings of Western Science: The European Scientific Tradition in Philosophical, Religious, and Institutional Context, 600 B.C. to A.D. 1450.", ''Speculum'', Vol. 69, No. 4 (October 1994), 1211.</ref>
''The Beginnings of Western Science'' focuses on the theoretical dimension of classical and mediaeval science, giving less attention to technology and scientific craft.<ref>David C. Lindberg, ''The Beginnings of Western Science: The European Scientific Tradition in Philosophical, Religious, and Institutional Context, 600 B.C. to A.D. 1450'', 2007 edition, 3.</ref><ref name = "Angela Smith's review">Angela Smith, [https://www.h-net.org/reviews/showrev.php?id=24125 "An Origin Story"], ''H-Net'', May 2009. Retrieved 4 October 2015.</ref> Lindberg defends a moderate view on the [[continuity thesis]], accepting continuity between early modern science and mediaeval antecedents but also identifying a scientific revolution in the cosmology and metaphysics behind science.<ref>David C. Lindberg, ''The Beginnings of Western Science: The European Scientific Tradition in Philosophical, Religious, and Institutional Context, 600 B.C. to A.D. 1450'', 2007 edition, 359, 364-367.</ref> [[Vivian Nutton]] states that Lindberg emphasizes discontinuities over continuities between mediaeval and renaissance science.<ref name = "Vivian Nutton's review p81">Vivian Nutton, "David C. Lindberg: The Beginnings of Western Science. The European Scientific Tradition in Philosophical, Religious, and Institutional Context, 600 B.C. to A.D. 1450.", ''The British Journal for the History of Science'', Vol. 26, No. 1 (March 1993), 81.</ref>
The book has found wide acclaim and is considered a good general introduction to the history of science in the West before the [[Renaissance]].
== Contents == The expanded edition begins with debates over definitions of science. Next, possible precursors to science are treated in the forms of knowledge prehistoric societies and theories about the notions of truth that would apply in such cultures. The section about Egyptian and Babylonian science starts with the differences in their types of arithmetic. Lindberg states that the Babylonian notation is superior because of its greater parsimony. Babylonian astrology, with the important development of [[horoscopic astrology]], is mentioned as a major contribution of Babylonian civilization. Egyptian and Babylonian medicine are described as systemizations of diagnoses, which often included non-naturalistic formulations.<ref>David C. Lindberg, ''The Beginnings of Western Science: The European Scientific Tradition in Philosophical, Religious, and Institutional Context, 600 B.C. to A.D. 1450'', 2007 edition, 1-20.</ref>
Greek science first covers the philosophies of the [[Pre-Socratic philosophy|pre-Socratics]], [[Plato]] and [[Aristotle]], after which the narrative continues with the Hellenistic philosophical schools, the [[Plato's Academy|Academy]], the [[Lyceum]], the [[Epicureans]] and the [[Stoics]]. Major figures in mathematics are [[Euclid]] and [[Archimedes]], and [[Eudoxus of Cnidus|Eudoxus]] and [[Claudius Ptolemy]] (discussed as part of Hellenistic astronomy) in astronomy.
== Themes == A central theme underlying the narrative of ''The Beginnings of Western Science'' is that classical and mediaeval science must be treated relative to their context, according to their own standards.<ref name="Vivian Nutton's review p81"/><ref name = "F Jamil Ragep's review p383">F. Jamil Ragep, "David C. Lindberg. The Beginnings of Western Science: The European Scientific Tradition in Philosophical, Religious, and Institutional Context, Prehistory to A.D. 1450." in ''Isis'', Vol. 10, No. 2 (June 2009), 383.</ref> F. Jamil Ragep also states that the rejection of [[Presentism (literary and historical analysis)|presentism]] is an important theme in the book.<ref name="F Jamil Ragep's review p383"/>
Several reviewers commented on the book's take on [[science and religion]]. Vivian Nutton mentions that one point that Lindberg makes is that religious traditions have influenced the development of science.<ref name="Vivian Nutton's review p81"/> Jamil Ragep notes that the [[warfare thesis]] is rejected.<ref name="F Jamil Ragep's review p383"/>
Methodology was another topic that commenters singled out. Angela Smith identifies the discussion of the methodological importance of mathematics and experimentation in science as a recurrent theme throughout ''The Beginnings of Western Science''.<ref name="Angela Smith's review"/> Jamil Ragep says that the notion that Aristotelian methodology was a positive contribution to science is tacitly accepted in the book.<ref name="F Jamil Ragep's review p383"/>
According to Smith, other themes in ''The Beginnings of Western Science'' are problems with definitions of science and "the philosophical implications of different concepts of change".<ref name="Angela Smith's review"/> Nutton maintains that Lindberg portrays science as a tradition that "may be no less difficult" to maintain than to create.<ref name="Vivian Nutton's review p81"/>
== Reception == [[Peter Harrison (historian)|Peter Harrison]] called the first edition "[t]he best general introduction to classical and medieval science."<ref>Peter Harrison, "Handmaiden Metaphor", in Heidi A. Campbell and Heather Looy (eds.) , ''A Science and Religion Primer'', 118.</ref> [[Vivian Nutton]] considered the work "solid and accurate", but lamented Lindberg's traditional choice of subject matter. He besides thought that his limited inclusion of late mediaeval scientists, particularly in the field of medicine, hurt his argument to stress discontinuity with the renaissance era.<ref>Vivian Nutton, "David C. Lindberg: The Beginnings of Western Science. The European Scientific Tradition in Philosophical, Religious, and Institutional Context, 600 B.C. to A.D. 1450.", ''The British Journal for the History of Science'', Vol. 26, No. 1 (March 1993), 81-82.</ref> William A. Wallace considered ''The Beginnings of Western Science'' "most welcome", but also stated he had reservations about the omission of several details he considered necessary for an introduction and criticized Lindberg's decision to comment on the continuity thesis while his book doesn't include [[renaissance science]].<ref>William A. Wallace, "David C. Lindberg, The Beginnings of Western Science: The European Scientific Tradition in Philosophical, Religious, and Institutional Context, 600 B.C. to A.D. 1450.", ''Speculum'', Vol. 69, No. 4 (October 1994), 1213.</ref> F. Jamil Ragep criticizes the book's first edition as [[Eurocentric]]. He notes that it claimed that Islamic science declined in the thirteenth and fourteenth centuries and hardly anything remained by the fifteenth century. The book also didn't emphasize the role of Babylonian science, especially in mathematics.<ref>F. Jamil Ragep, "David C. Lindberg. The Beginnings of Western Science: The European Scientific Tradition in Philosophical, Religious, and Institutional Context, Prehistory to A.D. 1450." in ''Isis'', Vol. 10, No. 2 (June 2009), 383-384.</ref> Richard C. Dales also thought that Lindberg undervalued Babylonian, but also Egyptian science. He in addition critiques Lindberg's description of twelfth-century science until the [[Latin translations of the 12th century|translation movement]]. His overall verdict is nonetheless that ''The Beginnings of Western Science'' is a "triumph" and "an authoritative account of Western science from its beginnings to the height of medieval scientific achievement".<ref>Richard C. Dales , "David C. Lindberg. The Beginnings of Western Science: The European Scientific Tradition in Philosophical, Religious, and Institutional Context, 600 B.C. to A.D. 1450.", in ''The American Historical Review'', Vol. 98, No. 3 (June 1993), 823.</ref>
Angela Smith considered the second edition of ''The Beginnings of Western Science'' a substantial success and thought it "a fundamental and reliable resource for many years to come".<ref name="Angela Smith's review"/> She appraised the improvements in the treatment of Islamic science to include recent scholarship in particular. Jamil Ragep calls it "a fine book, the culmination of a century of distinguished research on premodern European science" but also contends that the second edition still has a Eurocentric bias. He argues for inclusion of Chinese, Indian and Central-Asian influences on Western science.<ref>F. Jamil Ragep, "David C. Lindberg. The Beginnings of Western Science: The European Scientific Tradition in Philosophical, Religious, and Institutional Context, Prehistory to A.D. 1450." in ''Isis'', Vol. 10, No. 2 (June 2009), 384.</ref>
